doc.after: The core of the Sun extends from the center to about 20â25% of the solar radius.[65] It has a density of up to 7005150000000000000â 150Â g/cm3[66][67] (about 150 times the density of water) and a temperature of close to 15.7 million kelvin (K).[67] By contrast, the Sun's surface temperature is approximately 5,800Â K. Recent analysis of SOHO mission data favors a faster rotation rate in the core than in the rest of the radiative zone.[65] Through most of the Sun's life, energy is produced by nuclear fusion in the core region through a series of steps called the pâp (protonâproton) chain; this process converts hydrogen into helium.[68] Only 0.8% of the energy generated in the Sun comes from the CNO cycle, though this proportion is expected to increase as the Sun gets older.[69]
